block.p: British Airways Is Seen In Early Talks With KLM Amid renewed pressure in the airline industry to consolidate, British Airways has held informal merger talks with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, executives close to both companies said.

While the executives stressed that the discussions are preliminary, they underscore the frenzy among airline operators to seek partners hoping to increase profit in an industry that has seen its margins steadily erode. The informal talks take place amid the proposed acquisition of US Airways by UAL for $4.3 billion and overtures from AMR to Northwest about combining their businesses. [Page C2.]

I.B.M. in Venture With Salesforce I.B.M. and Salesforce.com, which offers software for managing sales data like contacts, leads and follow-ups, as a subscription service from its Web site, plan to announce a partnership intended to help small businesses transform themselves into e-businesses. [C7.]

Technology Deals That Went Wrong In no sector of the technology business have more companies with less revenue been acquired for richer sums than in communications equipment. On the surface, many of these deals look good for everyone, and they often are. But not every deal can be a success, and as the pace of acquisitions grows, so may the number of bad deals. New Economy. [C3.]

Online Integration, Except for Taxes Many traditional retailers have vowed that by integrating their Web operations into their physical stores, they will eventually bury Internet-only merchants. But even as these companies preach the gospel of Internet integration to the public, some of the best-known merchants are telling government regulators that their Internet and physical-world operations are distinct and separate businesses -- and therefore should enjoy the tax advantages of maintaining separate operations. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C10.]

Movie to Be Transmitted Digitally On Tuesday, for the first time ever, a movie will be digitally transmitted across the country over the Internet and then digitally projected to a cinema audience, going from the studio in Hollywood to a theater in Atlanta without ever touching film. The idea is to demonstrate the potential of digital distribution -- which many think will one day supplant traditional canisters of celluloid. [C6.]

Telewest in Talks for Chello Stake Telewest Communications, Britain's second-biggest cable company, is in talks to acquire about 10 percent of Chello Broadband, a unit of United Pan-Europe Communications. [C2.]

Small Booksellers Take Fight to Web Independent booksellers, which have fought a two-decades war against chains and, more recently, online booksellers, are seeking to gain ground on the Internet with two large-scale Web sites. On June 6, the American Booksellers Association will introduce Booksense.com, a ''hub site'' for hundreds of individual sites created and maintained by local stores. Next to come, in early July, is Contentville, in which about 40 of the most respected booksellers will provide editorial content. ''Booksense.com and Contentville can all act to remind consumers that independent booksellers have a valuable voice,'' said Roxanne Coady of R. J. Julia Books in Madison, Conn., who is participating in both sites. [C11.]

A Rematch for Hit TV Shows After uncertainty about the possible consequences, ABC will again pit the hottest show of the season, ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' against CBS's highly promising newcomer ''Survivor'' on Wednesday night. [C11.]

Salon's Redesign of Its Redesign Hoping to soothe ruffled readers, the online magazine Salon pulled back its site redesign, which had elicited an immediate chorus of e-mail boos and hisses from readers, and introduced another new design. [C3.]
